reflections.self_assessment: I stayed aligned with team evil’s needs by helping secure the critical mid-to-late missions and letting Merlin get blamed elsewhere, contributing to a clean 3–1 mission win without drawing too much suspicion. I could improve by more actively shaping the narrative around who looked like Merlin (especially pushing harder suspicion on Bob as Percival) to create more confusion earlier.

player_observations.Bob: Played a cautious, information-focused Percival game, often centering himself in early teams and trying to keep a stable core, which made him look reliably good and influential in team selection.
player_observations.Charlie: Appeared straightforward and relatively trusting, willing to go on and support early missions without overthinking, which kept them from being a major suspicion magnet but also from strongly driving the table’s reads.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, stayed subtle and careful, nudging teams just enough to avoid disaster but not loudly enough to draw obvious assassin-style attention until later missions made her reads more apparent in hindsight.
player_observations.Eve: Played a low-key Mordred who blended in well, taking high-impact fails (like Mission 3 or 4) while not loudly steering discussions, which helped keep heat off both of us as coordinated evil partners.
player_observations.Frank: Showed a generally trusting, cooperative good playstyle, joining and approving teams that seemed socially safe, which made them look genuinely good but also left them somewhat vulnerable to being steered by evil voices.

reflections.self_assessment: I managed information reasonably well by subtly protecting Diana and Eve as likely good while not making my reads so obvious that I got immediately targeted, which helped us secure three successful missions. However, I could have done more to cast doubt on Bob and Frank earlier—especially after Mission 3’s double fail—without making it look like I had extra information, as the assassin still came close by picking Charlie, indicating my cover as Merlin was only moderately convincing.

player_observations.Bob: You played a very steady, low-friction evil game—Mission 2’s clean success with you on the team helped you look safe, and you didn’t overtalk or over-defend, which made you blend in well as Morgana.
player_observations.Charlie: You came across as actively engaged and reasonably trusting, which fit Percival well, but your pattern of accepting teams and your general openness may have given evil some leverage in reading your role and steering your suspicions.
player_observations.Diana: You took a quiet but solid good approach, and your Mission 4 team choice (Diana, Eve, Charlie) landed well—your decisions seemed more intuitive than argumentative, which made you appear authentically good.
player_observations.Eve: You felt cautious but cooperative, generally willing to go along with plausible good narratives without forcing yourself into the spotlight, which helped maintain a stable, trustworthy table presence.
player_observations.Frank: You played a convincingly helpful teammate early, especially by passing Mission 1 with me, which gave you credibility; your willingness to be on multiple teams without raising alarms made your Mordred role quite hard to pin down without hidden info.

reflections.self_assessment: I played solidly safe and uncontroversial, which helped all three missions pass without raising suspicion or causing chaos. However, I could have been more active in questioning and reading others’ behaviors—staying too quiet made me more of a passenger than someone actually protecting Merlin and shaping good team composition.

player_observations.Bob: Played cautiously but with a slightly protective lean toward certain players, which fits well with Percival trying to narrow down Merlin vs Morgana without making it obvious.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as straightforward and trustworthy, voting and teaming in a very consistent, low-flash way that made them seem reliably good throughout.
player_observations.Diana: Blended in extremely well as evil by supporting clean missions and not pushing any overt agenda, which is classic Morgana play—ambiguous enough to be read as a possible Merlin or strong good.
player_observations.Eve: Played a very low-heat Merlin game, guiding teams toward all-success missions while staying understated enough that the assassin still found them but without ever looking blatantly obvious to everyone.
player_observations.Frank: Stayed under the radar and let others drive the narrative, which is an effective Mordred approach—dangerous because there was very little concrete information to pin on them as evil.

reflections.self_assessment: I managed to guide most of the team selections toward successful missions, especially keeping Diana off the final mission while still pushing for the right teams. However, I was too transparent in how confidently I cleared Bob and Charlie and how I kept subtle but consistent suspicion on Diana, which made me stand out as Merlin and allowed the assassin to correctly target me.

player_observations.Bob: Played straightforwardly and consistently approved good teams, which made him look genuinely townie without overexplaining his logic. His reactions to mission results felt natural, helping him avoid attracting suspicion.
player_observations.Charlie: Leaned into the information role vibe, projecting a bit of extra confidence that fit well with being Percival and helped shield Merlin somewhat early on. Occasionally looked almost too sure about certain reads, which could make him a future assassination target instead of a decoy.
player_observations.Diana: Blended very well into the good team early by accepting reasonable teams and not pushing overly hard, then used that trust to slip onto the failing mission. Her play as Mordred was subtle and disciplined, never panicking after the failed mission and keeping her tone steady.
player_observations.Eve: Flew under the radar and didn’t strongly drive team compositions, which kept them from being suspected heavily but also limited their influence on correcting course. Their low-key style made them appear more like a passive good player than a threat.
player_observations.Frank: Played Morgana convincingly by adopting a confident, somewhat ‘informed’ tone that could confuse perceptions between Merlin and Morgana. Coordinated well with the evil narrative around mission 3, and stayed just ambiguous enough to keep the assassination window open on the real Merlin.

reflections.self_assessment: I did well maintaining a generally trustworthy image and supporting early successful teams, but I failed to correctly distinguish Merlin from Morgana and didn't press hard enough on the implications of the late mission fails. I need to be more vocal about my Merlin read earlier and reevaluate my assumptions after each mission result instead of clinging to an initial narrative.

player_observations.Bob: Played very solid, central 'good leader' vibes by being on early successful missions and using that to anchor trust later, which effectively masked his Mordred role.
player_observations.Charlie: Stayed relatively out of the spotlight early and let others define the narrative, which is a classic Morgana approach that made their potential Merlin signals harder to confidently read.
player_observations.Diana: Gave subtle but consistent nudges toward good team compositions without over-asserting, which is strong Merlin play but also made it easier for evil to keep her from becoming an obvious target.
player_observations.Eve: Came across straightforward and earnest, generally accepting popular team proposals and projecting a very natural good-player mindset, though occasionally a bit too trusting of established narratives.
player_observations.Frank: Adopted a cautious, somewhat reactive style—more following the table’s logic than driving it—which made him look generically good but not especially cleared until the late missions.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently trustworthy on missions and helped establish a solid core by supporting the same successful team compositions, which contributed to securing three clean mission successes. I could improve by being more vocal in publicly challenging the narrative after the Mission 3 fail, as I relied a bit too much on quiet consistency rather than actively shaping the table’s suspicions.

player_observations.Bob: Played very much like a coordination anchor, repeatedly backing stable teams and projecting a calm, logical good-aligned vibe, which fit his Percival role well. He seemed to carefully avoid over-clearing anyone, which probably helped keep Merlin safer.
player_observations.Charlie: Subtly guided team selections without drawing too much attention, giving just enough resistance at key moments to steer us away from worse lineups. His balance of influence and restraint was very Merlin-like in hindsight, but in real time it was just quiet, credible leadership.
player_observations.Diana: Stayed relatively low-impact this game, which made her harder to pin as evil and kept suspicion from focusing on her. Her lack of strong pushes likely helped her Morgana role avoid being heavily scrutinized.
player_observations.Eve: Managed to blend in early by participating in a clean Mission 1 and then joining the mixed Mission 3 where the fail occurred, which created confusion about where the evil came from. She felt opportunistic in team votes, often okay with ambiguous lineups that preserved doubt.
player_observations.Frank: Set a trustworthy tone by leading a clean first mission and then not over-asserting himself afterward, which made him read very consistently good. His straightforward play and willingness to stick with proven teams helped reinforce the good bloc’s credibility.

reflections.self_assessment: I created early confusion with the Mission 1 fail and stayed reasonably hidden as Mordred, but I didn’t manage the narrative well enough to push suspicion onto Merlin by the final mission. I also failed to coordinate effectively with Eve/Morgana to frame a consistent alternative Merlin candidate, which weakened the assassin shot and let Diana stay too safe.

player_observations.Bob: Played a very controlled Percival game, repeatedly centering mission teams around himself while appearing cautious but fair, which helped him earn widespread trust. His consistency in including both Diana and Charlie without drawing too much heat was a big structural advantage for good.
player_observations.Charlie: Played a straightforward, low-flash good style, rarely over-arguing and instead quietly backing reasonable teams. That under-the-radar, steady behavior made it hard to credibly paint him as evil later on.
player_observations.Diana: Handled Merlin very subtly, mixing strong advocacy for good teams (especially the Bob/Charlie core) with just enough doubt to avoid looking omniscient. She timed her pushes well and never over-explained her reads, which kept her off the top of my assassin list.
player_observations.Eve: As Morgana, she did a good job mirroring a reasonable good player, but we didn’t sync our stories tightly enough to sell a cohesive false Merlin narrative. Her willingness to go along with the later safe teams contributed to her staying mostly unchallenged but also didn’t create enough misdirection at the end.
player_observations.Frank: Came off as a bit more suspicious after Mission 1 but then played in a way that didn’t strongly challenge the emerging consensus, which ironically helped him fade into the background as a plausible but not priority suspect. His relatively quiet presence made him an appealing—but ultimately wrong—assassination guess.

reflections.self_assessment: I did well blending in early by being on both Mission 1 and 2 successful teams, which helped build trust around me and obscured the evil team. However, I could have coordinated better with Eve on Mission 3 to shape the narrative after the double-fail and more actively push suspicion toward non-Merlin good players, since we ultimately failed to protect Merlin and misled the Assassin toward Bob instead of Frank.

player_observations.Bob: Played in a very low-key, non-flashy way that made him a plausible Merlin candidate, especially after being on mixed-result teams without drawing heavy suspicion.
player_observations.Charlie: Leaned into a proactive, central role by leading important missions and likely used their Percival info to keep pressure off the real Merlin while still questioning team compositions just enough to appear reasonable.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as straightforward and generally trusting, backing successful teams and not over-pushing accusations, which made her seem reliably good without screaming power role.
player_observations.Eve: Took a bolder risk by failing Mission 3 alongside me, contributing to heavy chaos but also attracting attention; their style felt more aggressive and opportunistic than quietly deceptive.
player_observations.Frank: Played a very controlled, subtle Merlin game—joined the key successful Mission 4 team without over-directing earlier rounds, giving helpful but not overtly prophetic-seeming guidance that kept him under the radar enough to avoid the final assassination.

reflections.self_assessment: I blended in reasonably well on the early missions and didn’t create much suspicion, but I failed to generate enough doubt around Merlin’s identity, which made the assassination miss. Next time, I should push harder to create competing Merlin narratives (especially around Charlie and Bob) and be more proactive in shaping table talk instead of mostly riding along with the successful teams.

player_observations.Bob: Played very cleanly and quietly, accepting teams and results without drawing much attention, which made you look like generic good rather than a power role—this low-key style helped hide Merlin effectively.
player_observations.Charlie: As Percival, you seemed cautious but willing to back successful patterns, and you didn’t over-assert your information, which kept evil from locking onto you as a power role while still subtly guiding team choices.
player_observations.Diana: You came across as straightforward and trustworthy, consistently landing on correct teams without a lot of drama, which reinforced the narrative that the early success streak was just good players making solid reads.
player_observations.Eve: You stayed nicely under the radar as Mordred, but we didn’t manufacture enough visible disagreement or failed missions together, which made the board state too clean and ultimately made it easy for good to win.
player_observations.Frank: You played a very low-profile Merlin, guiding team selections just enough to keep missions clean while never sounding like you had strong hidden info, which made the final assassination guess drift away from you.

reflections.self_assessment: I got too fixated on clearing myself and trusting early successes instead of aggressively re-evaluating when missions 2 and 3 failed. I should have pushed harder on vote logic and role distribution (especially around who could be Merlin/evil) before proposing my mission 4 team.

player_observations.Bob: Played a very central, talkative role and used his position on early teams to anchor discussions, which fit well with a Percival who’s trying to look informed but made it hard to separate his genuine reads from possible misdirection in real time.
player_observations.Charlie: Stayed relatively low-key and reactive, tending to follow the emerging consensus more than drive it, which made him seem safely good but also kept him from strongly challenging bad team proposals.

player_observations.Eve: Played Mordred very quietly and opportunistically, letting others take the spotlight while she benefited from the confusion around mid-game fails, which made it difficult to pin concrete suspicion on her.

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated early missions decently as leader on Mission 1 and tried to use mission results to narrow down Merlin, but I clearly misread the Morgana/Merlin signals and didn’t protect Diana effectively. Next time I need to be more disciplined about separating my reads on who is good from my reads on who is Merlin, and reevaluate harder after each failed mission instead of anchoring on my early assumptions.

player_observations.Frank: Came across as flexible and cooperative, generally willing to go with consensus teams; as a good player this helped him avoid suspicion, but it also let evil steer some key mission compositions.

reflections.self_assessment: I blended in reasonably well on early missions, especially by leading a clean Mission 2, which helped build my apparent credibility as good. However, I failed to correctly read the Merlin–Percival pairing and overestimated Charlie’s likelihood of being Merlin, which cost us the assassination; I also could have coordinated more clearly (through team choices and voting patterns) with Frank to better manage suspicion after the double-fail on Mission 3.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled Merlin game: she took quiet but consistent risks with mission team approvals that nudged outcomes without drawing heavy suspicion, especially by being on and supporting early successful missions.
player_observations.Charlie: Leaned into a visible, talkative role that looked like classic Percival, often publicly processing team choices and mission results in a way that made it hard to tell if he had extra information or was just overthinking, which successfully drew my focus in the assassination phase.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly trusted both Diana and Eve enough to keep missions clean, but I didn't do enough as Percival to create real ambiguity between who I was treating as Merlin and who I was treating as Morgana. In future games, I should be more deliberate about signaling protection for one of the suspects while occasionally casting doubt or soft suspicion on the real Merlin to misdirect the Assassin.

player_observations.Alice: Played consistently pro-mission and ended up on all three successful teams, suggesting a straightforward, trust-building good-playstyle that made her feel reliably safe to include.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-mission and helped secure early successes, which should have made me a reliable anchor for team proposals. player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled Merlin game, feeding just enough info to keep early missions clean while still looking somewhat plausible as a regular good. Her endgame composure under suspicion helped evil find her in the assassination phase.
player_observations.Charlie: Leaned into an active information-gathering style as Percival, often staying central to team discussions and missions. player_observations.Diana: Blended in well as Mordred, especially by being included on the failed Mission 3 without drawing lasting heat afterward. She managed to avoid becoming a default suspect despite being on the only fail, which was key to the evil team’s win.
player_observations.Eve: Played a quieter, low-impact good game, which kept them off most people’s radar both as a threat and as a strong source of information. Their neutrality made it harder for the table to confidently build or eliminate certain worlds.

reflections.self_assessment: I timed my visible support for early missions well, which built enough trust to get onto critical teams while staying under the radar as evil. player_observations.Alice: Very assertive in team discussions and seemed comfortable taking leadership, which helped her get on many teams but also made her a focal point for suspicion after the first fail. player_observations.Charlie: Played a relatively low-profile Morgana, which helped avoid direct heat while still subtly nudging suspicion elsewhere. Their presence on the final failing team suggests they were good at appearing just trustworthy enough to be included without heavy scrutiny.

player_observations.Eve: Came across as very straightforward and genuinely good-leaning, which made her an attractive and consistent team pick. However, that same predictability sometimes made her easier to manipulate into accepting slightly risky teams that still felt safe to her.

This analytical style made him valuable in discussions, but also left him vulnerable when evil could feed him just enough plausible logic to get him to back a losing team.

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated pretty well with Charlie once I suspected he was Merlin, especially by backing his team suggestions on Missions 2 and 4 and not over-explaining why I trusted him. I could improve by pushing harder after Mission 3’s fail to frame the suspicion more clearly on Diana/Eve instead of letting the evil team keep the pool of suspects too wide. I also should have left a few more intentional "false trails" about who I thought Merlin was so the assassin had a harder time locking in on Alice.

player_observations.Alice: Took leadership confidently and proposed mostly safe, information-light teams that still moved the game forward, especially on Missions 2 and 4. player_observations.Charlie: Played a very controlled, subtle Merlin game—giving just enough guidance on teams without over-asserting or hard-clearing people, especially around Missions 2 and 4. player_observations.Frank: Opened the game with a simple, low-risk Mission 1 that didn’t generate much information but also didn’t raise suspicion on himself. reflections.self_assessment: I feel I did well at consistently backing the Bob-Charlie-Diana core once it started proving itself, which helped stabilize trust and secure the later missions. reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-good in mission choices and voting, especially supporting the clean Team 2 and the critical Team 4, which helped reinforce a trustworthy image and contributed to the win. player_observations.Alice: Played aggressively and leaned into early trust from the clean missions, which helped her sneak onto key teams before the double-fail on Mission 3 exposed her side. She balanced talking just enough to seem cooperative without overexplaining.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently trustworthy and helped secure clean teams, which contributed to three straight successful missions and kept suspicion relatively low on me despite the assassin’s final guess. player_observations.Alice: Played confidently and leaned into appearing trustworthy, which made her early leadership seem reasonable despite being evil (Morgana). She blended well with the successful mission outcomes, suggesting she’s good at riding along with safe teams to maintain cover.

player_observations.Frank: Frank balanced guiding the game and staying hidden very well as Merlin, consistently ending up on correct teams without looking overly informed. Their subtle influence on team composition clearly helped good win while still dodging the assassin’s final guess.

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with Bob early and helped secure a clean first mission, which built some initial trust for the good team. Could perhaps have weighed the mission-lead patterns and early-team behavior a bit more, which might have pointed more strongly toward Alice as Merlin.

reflections.self_assessment: I played fairly straightforwardly as good, which helped keep mission discussions calm and likely contributed to all three missions succeeding. player_observations.Bob: Seemed to take a more information-oriented approach, likely trying to read roles and protect Merlin as Percival, though without making overly strong public pushes that would expose their own role.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly read that Alice was a power role but didn’t do enough to protect her identity and misjudged how obvious her Merlin signals were to evil. I also could have been more vocal in shaping team comps after Mission 3’s fail to better test Diana and Frank instead of defaulting to previously safe teams.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very classic, talkative Merlin game—consistently nudging good teams without ever hard-pushing accusations, but her alignment consistency across all four missions made her look too clean and thus suspicious as Merlin.
player_observations.Bob: Steady and low-drama; he followed the emerging consensus and backed logically sound teams, which made him read generically good but not especially cleared or influential.
player_observations.Diana: Blended in well by accepting early good results and only revealing her impact on Mission 3, then smoothly re-integrated into discussion without over-defending, which kept suspicion of her relatively muted.

player_observations.Frank: Played a subtle Morgana, echoing reasonable logic and staying near Alice’s orbit just enough to plausibly contest the Merlin read without over-claiming it, which helped keep good confused about relative trust between them.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed mostly believable as a potential Merlin/percival candidate and helped keep suspicion spread out, especially by allowing early missions to pass and not overdirecting discussions. I could improve by more actively shaping the narrative earlier (especially around Mission 2–3) to frame specific goods as suspicious instead of mostly reacting, which would have given evil more control over team compositions.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very analytical Percival, constantly cross-checking voting patterns and mission results, but seemed slightly overconfident in her Merlin read, which made her pushes somewhat predictable and exploitable.
player_observations.Bob: As Mordred, he blended in well with the good team, especially by taking part in early successes, and kept his tone low-key and non-leading, which made him a very safe inclusion on teams.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, she was cautious and subtle, rarely hard-pushing any one narrative, which protected her identity but sometimes made her reads less influential in team debates.
player_observations.Eve: Tended to follow the louder voices and table consensus, which made her look fairly neutral/innocent but also made her easier to steer when constructing or criticizing teams.
player_observations.Frank: Played with a straightforward, almost mechanical logic focus—trying to deduce from mission outcomes more than social cues—which made him resistant to pure rhetoric but also a bit slow to adjust to evolving narratives.

reflections.self_assessment: I managed my Merlin info fairly well, subtly steering toward the correct teams on Missions 1, 2, and 4 without drawing too much suspicion, as shown by the assassin choosing Alice instead of me. I could improve by seeding clearer doubt on Mission 3’s failing team earlier and by giving Percival (Bob) slightly stronger, but still deniable, signals so evil had a harder time narrowing down Merlin.

player_observations.Alice: Played very solid, trustworthy good—her consistent inclusion on successful teams made her look like a safe core, which also helped shield me as Merlin when she was assassin’s guess.

player_observations.Frank: Played like a straightforward, information-light good—quiet but cooperative; his early trust in the Alice/Eve team on Mission 1 gave evil a bit of cover but also didn’t create major suspicion on him.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently loyal on every mission I was on and tried to anchor trust around the Bob/Charlie/Diana block after Mission 2, which helped stabilize good’s information. player_observations.Alice: Opened aggressively by putting herself on Mission 1 and then used the early fail to sow doubt without drawing too much attention to herself, which fit a low-key evil style. player_observations.Bob: Played a very steady, trust-building style and repeatedly pushed for the same core good team, which is consistent with a typical Percival trying to protect and reinforce who they think Merlin is. player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, she guided team selections subtly by consistently supporting the Bob/Charlie combo and avoiding Alice/Eve where possible, without making hard accusations that would expose her. player_observations.Frank: Came across as unsure and somewhat reactive, which made him look potentially suspicious after the Mission 1 fail but also less like a coordinated evil. His later inclusion on the final mission without causing a fail quietly confirmed him as good, but he didn’t strongly drive discussions or push his reads, which kept his influence limited.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-mission, helped secure strong early teams, and correctly avoided putting Alice or Eve on the final team after Mission 3 exposed at least two evils. However, I was too slow to fully pivot suspicion off Alice as a Merlin candidate and onto Frank, and I didn’t do as much as I could to clearly protect Frank with my public reads. In future games, I should be more vocal about my evolving Merlin reads and use my influence more deliberately in the last mission and discussion before the assassination.

player_observations.Alice: You played a very convincing early-game good, passing both Missions 1 and 2 in a way that made you a prime Merlin candidate. player_observations.Bob: You came across as straightforwardly good, especially by being on both a clean Mission 2 and the successful final Mission 4. Your relatively transparent logic and lack of over-adjustment after the Mission 3 fail likely contributed to the assassin mistaking you for Merlin.
player_observations.Diana: You felt steady and low-drama, which helped make the Mission 2 and Mission 4 teams feel safe when you were involved. Your leadership on Mission 2 was conservative but effective, and you didn’t overreact to the chaos after the double fail.
player_observations.Eve: You blended in well until Mission 3, then took the shot with a fail in a way that didn’t immediately single you out, especially since there were two fails. player_observations.Frank: You played a very subtle Merlin, staying mostly out of the spotlight until the later mission while still ending up on the critical winning team. player_observations.Bob: Maintained a very steady, trustworthy presence as Mordred, leveraging the early successes to anchor himself as ‘confirmed-ish’ and then slipping a single fail into mid/late missions in a controlled way.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed relatively consistent with my voting and didn’t attract much suspicion early, which helped evil get Mission 3 to fail. player_observations.Frank: Your early involvement on the failed M1 made you look suspicious for a while, but your later mission behavior and voting patterns helped clear you. player_observations.Frank: Came across as earnest and generally trustworthy but a bit indecisive; as leader on Missions 3 and 5, he seemed to lean too much on established trust (especially in Bob) rather than aggressively challenging earlier assumptions.

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated the Mission 3 fail without drawing too much suspicion directly onto myself, and I stayed reasonably consistent with my earlier voting and table talk. I should have pushed much harder to frame Bob as Merlin instead of Alice and paid more attention to Charlie’s subtle but accurate nudges on team selection that I underweighted in the assassination.

player_observations.Alice: Played straightforward and confidently, which made her look like a solid generic good rather than a power role, especially since she kept choosing the same core team without overexplaining.
player_observations.Bob: Behaved like a classic Percival, visibly protecting Alice and Charlie with mild but consistent support while avoiding bold Merlin-like reads, which should have been a bigger red flag.
player_observations.Charlie: Very controlled and precise with their influence on teams—especially in supporting the successful 2nd and 4th missions—subtly steering outcomes without making loud accusations.
player_observations.Diana: As Morgana, her alignment with my reads was a bit too close at times, which risked linking us together; she played aggressively but could have diversified her stated suspicions more.
player_observations.Frank: Early mission leader who seemed cautious and low-information, then largely faded into the background, which helped him stay uncontroversial and made it harder to read or leverage him for misdirection.

reflections.self_assessment: I blended reasonably well with the good team on Missions 3 and 5, especially by staying off early suspicious teams and not overpushing any single narrative. However, I could have done more to sow doubt about Diana specifically and to manipulate Percival’s perception, since our assassination read ended up being quite off. In future games, I should more actively shape the Merlin candidates rather than passively fitting into whatever consensus forms.

player_observations.Alice: Willing to take an early risk as leader on Mission 1, which set a strong deceptive tone for evil but also put some suspicion on you afterward. You seem comfortable playing aggressively early, which can be powerful but also dangerous if people track mission patterns closely.
player_observations.Bob: Played a very steady, measured game that fit the Percival role well, often anchoring team discussions around a core trust circle. You were good at maintaining consistent logic, which helped protect Merlin and steer teams away from obvious evil candidates.
player_observations.Charlie: Your play came across as straightforward and relatively transparent, which made you a solid, low-drama good player. You seemed to follow table logic more than push your own narratives, which helped you avoid heavy suspicion.
player_observations.Diana: You did an excellent job of looking reasonably cautious without over-defending yourself, which is tricky as Merlin. Your team selections and mission reads were subtle enough that evil couldn’t confidently lock onto you, especially with how well you coordinated implicitly with Bob.
player_observations.Frank: You appeared flexible and somewhat easy to include or exclude from teams, which made you a convenient pivot point in late-game team composition. Your playstyle didn’t strongly broadcast either alignment, which inadvertently helped good when you stayed off critical failed missions.

reflections.self_assessment: I did well coordinating the Mission 3 fail with Alice to finally put pressure on the good team, but I stayed too quiet and let Charlie and Frank build too much trust with others. I also didn’t do enough to frame Diana or Bob as potential Merlin candidates, which made the assassin’s job harder and let Frank slip by under the radar.

player_observations.Alice: Played Morgana aggressively but in a controlled way, taking the risky double-fail on Mission 3 while still managing to look somewhat like a frustrated good player rather than an obvious evil.
player_observations.Bob: Played straightforwardly and consistently, which made him a natural, believable good player and ultimately a plausible Merlin target for the assassin.
player_observations.Charlie: Took on a leadership and information-hub role, using Mission 1 and 2 successes to build a strong reputation and then leveraging that credibility to push a trusted narrative.
player_observations.Diana: Played a low-key, steady-good style—rarely drawing suspicion, which helped stabilize teams and contributed to the success of the later missions.
player_observations.Frank: Played Merlin very subtly, avoiding obvious hard pushes and instead nudging things just enough to keep good teams together, which made him blend in as a regular cautious good player.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed too cautious as Mordred, allowing all three missions to pass and giving Merlin very little pressure or ambiguity to work with, which made endgame reads easier for good. I should have coordinated a planned early fail with Alice to create at least one noisy mission and paid more attention to subtle behavioral clues from Frank that hinted at extra information.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very low-disruption Morgana, blending in as a solid, trustworthy proposer, which unfortunately made it harder for us to generate suspicion and chaos. Their restraint was good for staying hidden but didn’t create the classic Merlin/Morgana tension we needed.
player_observations.Bob: Maintained a consistently clean, straightforward good-player image, rarely overexplaining or forcing reads, which made him an easy but ultimately incorrect assassination target. His willingness to be on early successful teams without pushing hard for control felt very typical of relaxed good play.
player_observations.Charlie: As Percival, Charlie projected a cautious, somewhat probing presence, asking just enough questions to look engaged without painting a clear target on themselves. Their reads seemed deliberately conservative, which helped protect both Merlin and their own identity.
player_observations.Diana: Played in a very natural, low-flash manner, accepting teams and participating without drawing attention, which strongly contributed to a stable, low-conflict game state favoring good. Her lack of big, performative reads made her seem reliably good without ever looking like a power role.
player_observations.Frank: Frank’s behavior was subtly confident and aligned with good outcomes, especially in supporting teams that all ended up passing, which in hindsight looks like informed positioning from Merlin. He avoided loud, directive leadership and instead nudged things in a way that kept suspicion off himself while still guiding the table toward correct teams.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed relatively under the radar as Mordred while still being on the key failing team for Mission 2, which helped create enough doubt around others rather than myself. I could improve by more actively shaping the table narrative mid-game—especially pushing stronger, believable theories about who Merlin might be to further misdirect good after the mission failures started piling up.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to build trust through conservative team choices, which made her seem reliably good but also a bit passive in driving accusations and big-picture reads.
player_observations.Bob: Played very engaged and central, which fit well with Percival—he tried to anchor the table’s logic, but that visibility also made him easier to manipulate with misleading signals from evil.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as quieter and more reactive, often following the momentum of others’ reads rather than pushing strong independent theories, which made them a convenient player to keep in ‘uncertain but probably good’ territory.
player_observations.Diana: Leaned into a confident, proactive style as Morgana, which helped sell a strong pseudo-Merlin/percival identity and added confusion about information accuracy for the good team.
player_observations.Frank: Played a solid Merlin in terms of picking decent teams early, but stayed just cautious enough in hard-calling evils that it left room for us to muddy perceptions of who actually had good information.

reflections.self_assessment: I was too trusting of the mission 3 team and didn’t push hard enough to re-evaluate after the mission 2 fail, especially given how often Bob was getting onto teams. I also didn’t leverage the pattern of Diana and Eve being together on consecutive failing missions strongly enough to argue for excluding them, and I should have been more vocal about alternative team comps.

player_observations.Alice: Quiet but effective evil presence; slipped onto the mission 2 team without drawing much suspicion despite the fail, suggesting a preference for subtle influence rather than aggressive steering.
player_observations.Bob: Played a very central, confident role in early team selection, which helped him seem trustworthy and made it easy for evil to hide behind his apparent certainty.
player_observations.Charlie: Appeared cautious and relatively conservative in team choices, which made him look reasonably good-aligned, but he didn’t press hard enough to overturn suspicious team patterns after the first fail.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, she nudged team directions just enough to avoid looking obvious, but her inclusion on the failing mission 4 suggests her signals were either too subtle or got lost in table noise.
player_observations.Eve: Blended into teams smoothly and was willing to take fails at key points without over-explaining, suggesting a calm, low-drama evil style that capitalized on the trust already built around others.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently trusted through the first two missions and helped set up a deceptive narrative going into the larger team of Mission 3, which let evil get a key fail through. However, I didn’t do enough to cast doubt on Alice as Merlin or to create stronger alternative Merlin candidates, making it easier for good to survive the assassination. In future games I should be more vocal in shaping suspicion patterns and coordinating my visible behavior with other evil players.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled Merlin game, giving just enough soft guidance to keep early missions clean while not drawing too much direct suspicion. Her consistent inclusion of the right mixes on teams made her look like a solid, rational good player rather than an obvious seer.
player_observations.Bob: As Morgana, Bob blended in well and supported team choices that kept evil from being exposed too early, especially on Missions 1 and 2. He did not over-claim information, which helped reduce the contrast between his play and Alice’s more subtly informed decisions.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie played an active, central role and was willing to be on multiple critical teams, which is typical of a confident good player or a bold evil player. As Percival, he didn’t clearly out Alice or Bob as Merlin/Morgana to us, which helped keep the Merlin identity ambiguous from the evil side.
player_observations.Diana: Diana showed a straightforward, conservative playstyle, proposing a small, clean team for Mission 4 that signaled strong ‘by-the-book’ good alignment. She didn’t push many loud accusations, which made her look stable but not particularly information-driving.
player_observations.Eve: Eve appeared cautious and somewhat low-profile, which is often interpreted as generic good unless paired with strong contradictory data. Her inclusion on the final successful mission reinforced an image of quiet reliability rather than someone steering the table’s narrative.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed quiet enough as Mordred that good never seriously suspected me, and I helped maintain the illusion of a completely clean game so the Assassin could make a confident kill. I could improve by being a bit more active in shaping team compositions and discussion, so my influence is clearer without drawing suspicion.

player_observations.Alice: Plays in a very straightforward, trusting way early, which makes her seem reliably good but also somewhat easy to guide onto teams others propose.
player_observations.Bob: Approached the game analytically, focusing on consistency and patterns, but seemed slightly anchored to early impressions of who was good.
player_observations.Charlie: Played cautiously and was willing to go along with consensus teams, which kept them looking clean but also made them less of a driving force in table talk.
player_observations.Diana: Blended in well as evil by supporting clean missions and avoiding unnecessary conflict, presenting as a very stable and reasonable voice.
player_observations.Eve: Had strong table presence and subtly guided team choices, which fit Merlin’s role well but also created a noticeable leadership pattern that the Assassin could key in on.

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with fellow evil players by keeping my suspicion level low and allowing Merlin to feel comfortable enough to reveal themselves through their mission choices, which helped set up a clean assassination on Alice. I could improve by being a bit more proactive in subtly pushing alternative narratives about who Merlin might be, to create even more confusion among the good team without drawing attention to myself.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled Merlin, guiding missions effectively while staying on successful teams, but the consistency of being on all the approved mission teams made you stand out as a key decision-maker. Your confidence in team selections was helpful for good but also gave evil a solid signal for the assassination.
player_observations.Bob: Played like a straightforward, trusting good player—willing to go on teams and not overcomplicate the logic. Your low-heat, cooperative style made you look reliably good but not especially power-role-like, which kept suspicion off you in the late game.
player_observations.Charlie: Showed signs of being an information role by being consistently central in the mid-game and aligning strongly with Alice’s decisions. Your participation in both the successful and failed missions, plus your comfort taking leadership, hinted at you being more than a generic good player.
player_observations.Diana: Did a strong job as Mordred by blending in and taking an early mission with Alice without causing trouble, helping evil stay hidden through the first half of the game. You let others talk more and avoided being the focal point of logic debates, which kept suspicion on the more vocal players instead.
player_observations.Eve: Stayed relatively quiet or low-impact in terms of steering team compositions, which made you read as a background good player. That low-profile presence helped ensure you were rarely considered for key information roles, and you didn’t interfere much with the social reads that evil was exploiting.

reflections.self_assessment: I was too slow to lock in on Bob as the consistent source of mission fails and let that uncertainty push me into a risky final-team choice that included Charlie instead of a more statistically safe configuration. I did reasonably well trusting Diana and Eve by the end, but I should have pushed harder against keeping Bob on missions after Mission 3 and recognized the pattern of single-fail missions pointing to him.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very central information role and built trust early with clean missions, but her association with Bob on the failing Mission 4 made reading her alignment tricky from my perspective.
player_observations.Bob: Blended in extremely well as evil by anchoring early successful missions and then consistently sabotaging from inside trusted teams, leveraging that trust so we kept including him despite the pattern of single fails.
player_observations.Charlie: Stayed relatively under the radar for most of the game and benefited from not being heavily tested on early missions, which made it easier for you to slip onto the final team as hidden evil.
player_observations.Diana: Your play as Merlin was subtle but not forceful; you seemed to avoid hard accusations, which kept you safe but also made it harder for me to confidently follow your reads.
player_observations.Eve: Came across as steadily good and trustworthy through repeated successful missions and calm team selections, though your presence on failing teams with Bob made it hard to completely clear you until late.

reflections.self_assessment: I played solidly and stayed uncontroversial, which helped keep suspicion away from both me and the likely power roles while supporting generally good team selections. I could improve by being more vocal about structured reasoning for or against certain teams, so my reads influence the table more instead of mostly following others’ leads.

player_observations.Alice: She projected a very steady, trustworthy presence and leaned into consistent team choices, which made her a natural hub for team-building and a tempting assassin target.
player_observations.Bob: He was active and assertive in shaping teams, especially around Missions 2–4, which fit well with a power role trying to protect Merlin while still pushing the game in a clear direction.
player_observations.Charlie: He played cautiously but with just enough quiet influence on team compositions to steer things the right way without drawing too much attention, which makes sense now that we know he was Merlin.
player_observations.Diana: She stayed relatively under the radar and didn’t push hard narratives, which made it harder to pin her as evil but also meant she wasn’t a central force in team debates.
player_observations.Eve: She blended in well early by going on the first mission and keeping it clean, then introduced just enough doubt on the later mission to cause a fail without overexposing herself as a likely evil.

reflections.self_assessment: I recovered reasonably well after being on the failed Mission 1 team, staying calm and using later mission results to argue for my innocence without over-insisting. I could improve by more aggressively questioning the Alice/Eve axis earlier, as I let their conflicting narratives shape too much of the mid-game discussion instead of driving my own logic consistently.

player_observations.Alice: You played a very assertive evil Mordred, using the early fail on Mission 1 to seed long-lasting doubt on me while keeping just enough ambiguity around yourself to avoid being hard-cleared as evil too early. Your willingness to let others (especially Bob and Diana) steer mission compositions while you stayed vocally analytical helped you blend in for longer than I expected after a failed lead.
player_observations.Bob: As Percival, you leaned heavily into structured logic and consistency checks, which made your support for Diana later feel very convincing and stabilizing for the good team. You did a good job not over-clearing either Merlin candidate too loudly, which helped protect Diana, though at times your focus on tight, low-variance teams probably made you look a bit controlling.
player_observations.Charlie: You played a very low-drama, steady good role, and your willingness to repeatedly go on the same teams (even after a fail) suggested you were trusting the information flow more than trying to hero-guess. Your calm acceptance of being on both a failed and successful team without over-defensiveness made you look quite genuine and helped solidify the core good block.
player_observations.Diana: Your Merlin play was subtle and measured; you nudged team selections in the right direction (especially Missions 2 and 4) without ever hard-accusing Alice or Eve in a way that would expose you. The way you let some suspicion sit on me while still keeping me in the final mission team was a nice balance between protecting your identity and steering good to victory.
player_observations.Eve: As Morgana you did a strong job mirroring good logic and staying tightly paired with Alice in a way that made the evil team look internally consistent, especially around Mission 3’s fail. Your presence on both a failed and then a proposed final mission without pushing too hard to be included helped keep you from being the obvious scapegoat, even though your eventual exclusion from the last team was key to good’s success.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently cautious in how I signaled suspicions, which helped keep the assassin off me while still nudging teams toward mostly good lineups. I could have done a better job subtly steering people away from trusting Alice and Eve earlier—especially after the double-fail on Mission 3—without making my reads look too informed or decisive.

player_observations.Alice: You played aggressively and leaned into early trust, which made you a very plausible Merlin candidate after Mission 1 and 2 succeeded cleanly with you on both. The double-fail on Mission 3 was big, but you still maintained enough ambiguity that evil could have reasonably hoped you’d be read as Merlin over me.
player_observations.Bob: You played very straightforwardly and consistent with a loyal good, which made you look mechanically clean but not overly insightful—likely why you were a comfortable Merlin guess for the assassin. Your willingness to go on high-risk teams (like the Mission 3 lineup) without overdefending them helped you avoid looking too calculating.
player_observations.Charlie: You seemed to approach the game methodically, and as Percival you did a good job keeping suspicion spread between multiple Merlin candidates rather than tunneling. Your team choices, especially putting me on Mission 4, suggested you had some quiet reads but you didn’t broadcast them loudly enough to expose Merlin.
player_observations.Diana: You played a low-drama, logic-first game and your leadership on Mission 2 created a clean, trustworthy baseline for others to anchor on. Your choices and table talk felt very classically good, which helped reduce chaos and gave me room to make subtle nudges without needing to overexplain anything.
player_observations.Eve: Your evil play was patient—you didn’t push too hard early, which made your inclusion on the big Mission 3 team feel natural and unforced. The two FAILs there were brutal for good, and you handled the aftermath well by not overjustifying yourself, preserving enough ambiguity that suspicion didn’t lock solely on you.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed reasonably hidden as Merlin while still nudging people toward trusting Bob and Diana and keeping missions clean, which helped secure three straight successes and avoid any FAIL cards. I could improve by more actively sowing doubt about Alice and Eve earlier without making my resistance to them look too pointed, as that might have further reduced the odds of the assassin targeting a core good player like Bob.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very convincing Morgana, leaning into early team proposals that looked safe and not overpushing any sabotage, which made her feel like a cautious but cooperative good player. Her subtlety and lack of overt agenda pressure helped keep suspicion off her despite being evil.
player_observations.Bob: Came across as straightforward and consistent, with decisions that matched a typical good-player risk profile and no noticeable over-defensiveness, which made it easier to trust him. His willingness to go on early teams without hedging or angling for complex logic supported the image of a genuinely good agent.
player_observations.Charlie: Behaved like a careful information-gatherer, asking questions and evaluating team compositions in a way that matched a typical Percival profile. He didn’t tunnel too hard on any single read, which helped keep both Merlin candidates (Alice and me) plausibly in play for much of the game.
player_observations.Diana: Played a low-drama, cooperative style that fit well with a solid, dependable good role, especially by accepting and performing on early teams without creating noise. Her lack of strong agenda-driving made her an easy inclusion for missions once early successes started to stack up.
player_observations.Eve: Stayed relatively under the radar, which is often effective for Mordred, avoiding big, risky pushes that would draw attention to alignment. By not placing herself in key mission spots or debate focal points too aggressively, she made it harder for good to justify explicit suspicion without looking paranoid.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly suspected that Diana and Eve were likely evil relatively early, but I failed to communicate those reads clearly and safely enough through my voting and team suggestions. I also didn’t do enough to protect Bob as Percival or guide town toward consistent, trusted cores, which made it easier for evil to control the narrative and mission selections.

player_observations.Alice: Played straightforwardly and took reasonable risks in team selection, but didn’t press hard enough on vote patterns to distinguish between subtle evil and cautious good.
player_observations.Bob: Leant into his Percival role by being assertive in discussions and team formations, but occasionally over-committed to his reads, which made it easier for evil to let him drive bad teams without much resistance.
player_observations.Charlie: Played a relatively low-key, reactive game, often following emerging consensus; this made him look quite village but also limited his impact on correcting bad team directions.
player_observations.Diana: Blended in very well as Morgana by taking leadership spots and proposing plausible teams, using just enough apparent flexibility to avoid looking like the clear source of fails.
player_observations.Eve: As Mordred, stayed just outside the center of suspicion, influencing outcomes through a mix of quiet positioning and one key fail that didn’t fully implicate her, making her hard to nail down.
player_observations.Frank: N/A
